descriptionSet.description: This poster from the Oriental Calender Manufacturing Company shows a well dressed family - parents and two children (one son, one daughter) - sitting at a table for a meal in a room full of furniture such as a radio, a lamp and several pictures hanging on the wall. A pet dog lies at feet of woman.

inscription.text: ORIENTAL CALENDAR DUMDUM OCMCO [publisher's signet] (undecipherable line)

titleSet.title: Calendar page sample by Oriental Calendar Manufacturing

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: This poster from the Oriental Calender Manufacturing Company shows a well dressed family - parents and two children (one son, one daughter) - sitting at a table for a meal in a room full of furniture such as a radio, a lamp and several pictures hanging on the wall. A pet dog lies at feet of woman. (gs/cb)
text-en: ORIENTAL CALENDAR DUMDUM OCMCO [publisher's signet] (undecipherable line)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: When family members do appear in the modern home, women appear in the warm glow of compassionate marriage. When seated around the dining table they enter freely and openly into conversation with their husbands. (Abigail McGowan) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The meal seems to be breakfast, there is toast and tea/coffee on the table. This is overtly a 'happy family', all are smiling at each other, and the parents are following the principle of two children-policy, ideally, with one son and one daughter. All are clad in Western dress, with the exception of the homekeeper. The table is not made for more than 4 people, indicating the concept of the nuclear family as an 'ideal'. Radio, fan, lamp on a stand, curtains, framed pictures, all indicate the 'modern lifestyle' of an urbanised living. (cb)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The reason why the "ideal" woman in this "ideal" family wears a sari whereas her husband sits in a Western suit at the kitchen table is the following: A women's body was regarded as being more susceptible to external, respectively foreign influences (Rupal Oza 2006). In the second half of the 20th century it became a very prominent visual trope that men were defined in relation to their work, their class and modernity. Women were visually connoted to tradition, expressed by wearing traditional clothes. In the masculine visual rhetoric Western suits stood for a modern outlook to the world, economic success, prestige and a high level educational level (Chauan 2007: 159 f). (la)
related literature: Oza, Rupal 2006. The Making of Neoliberal India. Nationalism, Gender and the Paradoxes of Globalization. New Delhi: Women Unlimited. (la)

related literature: Chauan, Richa 2007. Seeking a suitable match. Econcomic Development, Gender, and Matrimonial Advertisements in India. In Janet Huber Lowry & Kamal K. Misra (Eds.). Recent Studies on Indian Woman. Jaipur: Rawat Publications, 152-170. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: According to Erving Goffman in "Gender Advertisements" visualisations of a family almost always entail four family members, ideally the parents, a boy and a girl. The husband, in line with his high status, is in most cases the central person on an image. (la)
